meanings.definition: Noun: an opening in a ship's side to allow water to drain from the deck
meanings.sent1: The sailor quickly plugged the scupper to stop water from flooding the ship.
meanings.sent2: During the storm, the scupper efficiently drained the rainwater off the deck.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous seagull used the scupper as a slide to have some fun.
meanings.sent4: The scupper became a lifeline as it directed the water away from the ship's interior.
meanings.sent5: The crew painted the scupper bright red for easy visibility in emergencies.

meanings.sent1: The massive wave threatened to scupper the small fishing boat.
meanings.sent2: The unexpected news seemed to scupper their plans for the weekend.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was so impressive, it seemed to scupper reality itself.
meanings.sent4: The fierce competition aimed to scupper the hopes of the underdog team.
meanings.sent5: The villain's evil plan was designed to scupper the hero's efforts at every turn.

meanings.definition: Verb: to prevent something from happening
meanings.sent1: The timely intervention managed to scupper the thief's escape.
meanings.sent2: The security measures were put in place to scupper any potential security breaches.
meanings.sent3: The clever disguise was meant to scupper any suspicions of the undercover agent.
meanings.sent4: The unexpected delay threatened to scupper their chances of arriving on time.
meanings.sent5: The detailed plan was carefully crafted to scupper any attempts at sabotage.
